DataElement.preferredName: PROMIS 43 Adult Profile v2.0 Global07 Past 7 Days How Would You Rate Your Pain On Average Score 11 Point Scale
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Persons' stated observation of the average amount of pain they felt in the past seven days, using a eleven-point visual analogue scale.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: PROMIS-43 Adult Profile v2.0 In The Past 7 Days How Would You Rate Your Pain On Average Score
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A 43-item multidimensional and universal measure of health intended for use across a variety of conditions. It measures an adult patient's self-reported health status in seven domains: physical function, anxiety, depression, fatigue, sleep disturbance, pain interference, and participation in social roles._A question about an individual's rating of the average amount of pain they have felt in the past seven days._A number or range of numeric values measuring performance, function, quality, or ability.

ValueDomain.preferredName: PROMIS Pain Rating Average Score 11 Point Scale
ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: A linear analogue scale used with PROMIS items for the subjective scoring of a person's average pain rating that ranges from 0: No pain to 10: Worst imaginable pain.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A subjective score of 10 on a scale for average pain that ranges from 0: No Pain to 10: Worst imaginable pain.

Concepts.definition: A subjective score of 10 on a scale for average pain that ranges from 0: No Pain to 10: Worst imaginable pain.

ReferenceDocuments.name: Using PRO/HRQoL Measures
ReferenceDocuments.description: This data element is part of a full set of items that comprise a PRO/HRQoL measure. The full set must be used without any changes to the questions or value set in order to retain the validity and reliability associated with the measure. The URL citation is provided so that caDSR users can obtain materials related to instructions for administering and/or scoring the measure. Changes may not be made to these documents. In cases where retaining the question set intact to preserve the validity and reliability are not as important as advancing the science, questions may be used individually or in combination with other measure questions.
